snippet: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off, but they declined to investigate the problem.
abstract: Data shows that federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints since 2003 about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off, but they declined to investigate the problem; GM now says defect is linked to 13 deaths and requires the recall of more than 1.6 million cars worldwide.

byline.original: By HILARY STOUT, DANIELLE IVORY and MATTHEW L. WALD
byline.contributor: Bill Vlasic, Kitty Bennett and Rebecca Ruiz contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off, but they declined to investigate the problem.

headline.main: Auto Regulators Dismissed Defect Tied to 13 Deaths
headline.print_headline: Auto Regulators Dismissed Defect Tied to 13 Deaths
